metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of hydrometeorological observation network (an automatic weather station of Sidaoqiao mixed forest station, 2014)
metadata.description:
This data set contains meteorological element observation data from January 1, 2014 to December 31, 2014 at the downstream mixed forest station of heihe hydrometeorological observation network.The station is located at sidao bridge, dalaihubu town, ejin banner, Inner Mongolia.The longitude and latitude of the observation point are 101.1335e, 41.9903n and 874m above sea level.The air temperature and relative humidity sensors are located at 28m, facing due north.The barometer is installed in the anti-skid box on the ground;Tilting bucket rain gauge installed at 28m;The wind speed and direction sensor is located at 28m, facing due north.The four-component radiometer is installed at 24m, facing due south;Two infrared thermometers are installed at 24m, facing due south and the probe facing vertically downward.Two photosynthetically active radiators were installed at a position of 24m, facing due south, with one probe vertically upward and one probe vertically downward.The soil temperature probe is buried at 0cm of the surface and 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 60cm and 100cm underground, 2m to the south of the meteorological tower.The soil water probe is buried 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 60cm and 100cm underground, 2m to the south of the meteorological tower.The soil heat flow plates (3 pieces) are buried in the ground 6cm underground, 2m to the south of the meteorological tower.
Observation items are: air temperature and humidity (Ta_28m, RH_28m) (unit: c, percentage), pressure (Press) (unit: hundred mpa), precipitation (Rain) (unit: mm), wind speed (WS_28m) (unit: m/s), wind (WD_28m) (unit: degrees), the radiation of four component (DR, UR, DLR_Cor, ULR_Cor, Rn) (unit: watts per square meter), the surface radiation temperature (IRT_1, IRT_2) (unit:(unit: Ts_0cm, Ts_2cm, Ts_4cm, Ts_10cm, Ts_20cm, Ts_40cm, Ts_60cm, Ts_100cm) (unit: Celsius), soil moisture (Ms_2cm, Ms_4cm, Ms_10cm, Ms_20cm, Ms_40cm, Ms_60cm, Ms_100cm) (unit:Volumetric water content, percentage), upward and downward photosynthetically active radiation (PAR_up, PAR_down) (in micromol/m2 seconds).
Processing and quality control of observed data :(1) ensure 144 pieces of data every day (every 10min), and mark by -6999 in case of data missing;Due to the data collector, part of the data was missing between 2014.5.9-6.8 and 2014.11.9-12.7.(2) excluding the time with duplicate records;(3) data that obviously exceeds the physical significance or the range of the instrument is deleted;(4) the part marked with red letter in the data is the data in question;(5) date and time have the same format, and date and time are in the same column.For example, the time is: September 10, 2014, 10:30;(6) the naming rule is: AWS+ site name.
For information of hydrometeorological network or station, please refer to Li et al.(2013), and for observation data processing, please refer to Liu et al.(2011).

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of meteorological and hydrological data collected from an automatic weather station in mixed forest environments?
Feature Specification.Answer: air temperature at 28m, relative humidity at 28m, atmospheric pressure at ground level, precipitation, wind speed at 28m, wind direction at 28m, four-component radiation, surface radiation temperature, soil heat flux, soil temperature at various depths, soil moisture at various depths, photosynthetically active radiation upward, photosynthetically active radiation downward

Definition.Question: What is the significance of deploying sensors at varying heights and depths in meteorological and hydrological research?
Definition.Answer: Deploying sensors at varying heights and depths allows for comprehensive data collection of different environmental parameters. For example, air temperature and relative humidity sensors are placed at 28 meters to capture atmospheric conditions, while soil temperature and moisture sensors are buried at various depths to monitor subsurface conditions. This approach helps in understanding the interactions between the atmosphere and the land surface, which is crucial for modeling and predicting ecological and hydrological processes.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the effectiveness of data collection methods and quality control measures from the observed patterns of missing data and marked uncertainties in a dataset?
Interpretation.Answer: The data collection methods and quality control measures indicate that efforts are made to ensure data completeness and accuracy, such as marking missing data with -6999 and excluding duplicates or out-of-range values. However, the presence of missing data during specific periods suggests challenges in data acquisition, possibly due to equipment limitations or environmental factors. The marking of questionable data in red further reflects a rigorous approach to maintaining data integrity.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to data gaps or errors in meteorological measurements in remote ecological stations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Data gaps or errors in meteorological measurements at remote ecological stations can be caused by several factors, such as equipment failures, like the data collector issues that led to data missing from May 9 to June 8 and November 9 to December 7 in 2014. Harsh environmental conditions might also affect sensor performance and data accuracy. Additionally, errors may arise from redundant records, measurements that exceed physical or instrumental limits, and questionable data indicated by anomalies which require further investigation.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences on data integrity when ensuring daily measurements with a frequency of 144 data points, especially when facing data loss or instrument limitations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Ensuring daily measurements with a frequency of 144 data points can lead to challenges in maintaining data integrity, particularly when data loss occurs due to instrument limitations or malfunctions, such as during specific periods when data is missing. The integrity can be compromised when missing data is marked with placeholders like -6999, potentially affecting the continuity and reliability of the dataset. Moreover, data integrity may also be impacted by the necessity to remove duplicate records or data points that exceed physical or instrumental ranges, which can lead to gaps or uncertainties in the dataset.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures should be followed to ensure the accuracy and quality control of meteorological data collected at a mixed forest station, considering potential issues such as missing data or instrument limitations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure the accuracy and quality control of meteorological data collected at a mixed forest station, several procedures should be followed: (1) Ensure that data is collected every 10 minutes, aiming for 144 data points daily, and mark any missing data with a placeholder (e.g., -6999). (2) Remove any duplicate records to maintain data integrity. (3) Delete data that significantly exceeds physical or instrument range limits. (4) Flag any questionable data in red for further review. (5) Standardize the format of date and time, ensuring they are in the same column, such as '2014-9-10 10:30'. These steps help maintain data quality despite challenges such as missing data due to data logger issues or data that falls outside expected ranges.

Enablement.Question: What techniques are used to ensure the accuracy and quality of meteorological and hydrological data collection in mixed forest environments?
Enablement.Answer: Data accuracy and quality in mixed forest environments are ensured through several methods such as ensuring a set number of daily data entries (144 entries per day, every 10 minutes), marking missing data with a specific code (-6999), removing duplicate records, eliminating data that exceed physical or instrument limits, marking questionable data with a specific notation, and maintaining consistent date and time formats.
